Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. A major consequence of climate change is increased temperature variation; however, most studies addressing temperature variation in climate change use constant temperatures and focus on adult organisms. This is problematic because many traits important to survival (e.g. metabolism) are not only temperature-sensitive, but are differentially affected by constant versus fluctuating temperatures. Further, developmental life stages may be more sensitive to temperature variation than adult life stages. This research will compare how developmental and adult life stages are affected by temperature variation, and the potential role of parents in mitigating the degree of temperature variation experienced by young. Findings from this work will enhance predictions of animal responses to climate change and ultimately aid conservation and management decisions. A key facet of the program will be carried out by high school students in the Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians (EBCI) during a summer STEM camp developed and led by the PI, her sponsor, and collaborators in the EBCI. The summer STEM camp will be evaluated and revised during the fellow's tenure, so that an effective outreach program can be implemented annually following the conclusion of the fellowship.

This work will determine if (1) temperature variation differentially affects organisms throughout ontogeny, and (2) assess the role of parents in mitigating the degree of thermal variability experienced by young. This project will utilize Onthophagus taurus, which exhibits discrete life stages and suites of parental effects, like variation in sub-surface brood ball burial depth. Brood ball burial depth may significantly contribute to the degree of thermal variability young experience during development, potentially affecting thermal sensitivity of metabolism, survival, and fecundity, ultimately influencing responses to climate change. To address the first research objective, the fellow will measure: (a) metabolic costs incurred under fluctuating temperatures, (b) degree of thermal plasticity, and (c) potential costs associated with mounting thermally plastic responses across life stages. The second research objective assess shifts in brood ball burial depth under current and predicted climates. Importantly, this research objective will be carried out by EBCI students annually, culminating in a longitudinal citizen science database that tracks climate-driven shifts in parental behavior. During the research program, the fellow will receive training in invertebrate physiology, quantifying thermal sensitivity of metabolism, and R. The fellow will also receive career development training from K. Sheldon and NIMBioS, and gain educational experience implementing culturally responsive practices and Traditional Ecological Knowledge.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to (1) better understand how organisms cope with thermal variability in their environment to enhance our ability to predict responses to rapid environmental change and (2) to increase opportunities for high school students from underrepresented groups in southern Appalachia to participate in STEM. This research used Onthophagus taurus dung beetles, in part, because research in this species can be more broadly applied across other ectothermic organisms like insects, reptiles, amphibians, and fish.

Most often, research focuses on the physiology and behavior of adults. Knowing how other life stages respond to temperature change is crucial, since models not based on the most vulnerable life stage may overestimate species persistence and cause the misallocation of conservation resources. To address this knowledge gap, we determined the ability of different life stages of O. taurus to cope with thermal variability by measuring plastic shifts in thermal sensitivity of metabolism (a metric that gauges energy expenditure under variable temperatures). We found that adults exhibited plasticity in this trait, which would help them conserve energy in fluctuating conditions for other functions like immunity, reproduction, and foraging. However, pupae, an earlier life stage, do not exhibit plasticity in this trait, potentially making them more susceptible to environmental change. Our findings emphasize the importance of considering life stages beyond adults when forecasting how environmental change may impact species.

We also examined how the "reproductive life stage" responds to thermal variability, since the physiology and behavior of mothers during reproduction can affect offspring survival. We allowed females to breed in field enclosures, half of which reproduced under greenhouses that increased temperature average and variation. We found that females buffered offspring from extreme temperatures by burying eggs (within broodballs) deeper in the soil, where temperatures are cooler and less variable. Though offspring survival rates were similar between the control and greenhouse treatments, offspring from the greenhouse treatment were smaller and exhibited skewed sex ratios which could influence offspring survival and fitness. Together, these findings demonstrate that parents can alter their behavior to help buffer offspring from (some) impacts of temperature change and highlight the need to further understand transgenerational responses to environmental change.

In addition to the above research goals, we also launched and led a summer STEM camp for high school students in rural Appalachia. The program was executed in collaboration with the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians (EBCI) Fisheries and Wildlife Department. We worked with students to design and carry out a field experiment with a locally native dung beetle species, Phanaeus vindex. Students collected and analyzed the data in R and prepared a presentation of major findings. Throughout the program, students also shadowed biologists in the EBCI Fish and Wildlife Department, gaining exposure to a diversity of STEM career opportunities. The program exposed students to various field techniques, the nature of research, entomology, coding, science communication, wildlife management, and traditional ecological knowledge.  Importantly, the program has been designed to run annually, even after the expiration of the NSF fellowship, in collaboration with the University of Tennessee and the EBCI Fish and Wildlife Department.
